revision_history.draft:
A steel bar emerges from the billet mold
already cooled to a hull of habit,
then transferred to the forge where air finds its work
and the carbon dissolves into the matrix as an atom would dissolve
into another atom's dance, the grains rearranging themselves
along grain boundaries they never crossed before,
all of this while still red-hot and held
in the cradle of tongs that do not compress but align,
as fingers might.

The bar is bent twice its length and kept there—
yield strength defined—and sent to the press
where it is forced into a die shaped like a cylinder's cross-section,
under pressure larger than any force it carried when drawn from fire,
and something happens at the molecular level: some dislocations
step forward, others are trapped, the lattice reorganizes
with fewer defects, all of this while still glowing,
still carrying heat as property rather than temperature.

The bar is cut with a saw that does not grind but slices
through by virtue of being thin and hard,
and from the cut face a puddle of iron and carbon gathers,
not molten in the sense of boiling but softened
enough to sag, and here the writer infers: this is what happens
when an object gives up its crystalline order entirely—
it pools like a language losing its grammar.

The cylinder is swaged next, reduced in diameter
by repeated passes through dies that are getting smaller,
each one leaving the metal slightly denser, slightly more
like whatever it will become, and at this point the heat has left
but not been missed—the grain structure has locked into place
with no memory of its history except stiffness.

The cylinder sits on a shelf in a warehouse
where temperature fluctuates with weather,
and what happens is not rust but work hardening,
the grains resisting further deformation by tightening their bonds,
a kind of crystalline anxiety, and the surface darkens
through atomic abrasion rather than through corrosion—

it should be said: this object has been shaped
by forces that had no name for it.

Then: a drill bit presses into the side wall,
advances in chip sizes too small to see with naked eye,
and what the metal does is yield layer by layer, each grain
sliding past its neighbor like water finding fissures
in the rock over hundred thousand years,
and this is how the bore is made—
not by removing material but by teaching it a new pore.

The drill exits and the operator threads a pin into the hole
and the bar goes to the lathe where turning cuts
along the length, producing chips that curl off backward
from the rotating workpiece in the shape of a spiral
that looks like something deposited rather than removed—

this is because cutting is not subtraction,
it's interruption: the tool passes through and leaves
a softer version behind.

The bar is now a bolt. It goes into assembly.
Somewhere, under load, it yields at its thread roots
and work hardens there—the grains pile up against each other
in that small circle until the bolt threads seize
on their own mating nut as if on a mineral lode,
and here the object has reached its most solid phase:

not heat treated but pressure set.

What happens after use is not named.
The bolt sits in soil and the iron begins to diffuse
from grain to grain where it meets carbon—
this is why buried steel rusts from the inside out: anion vacancies
arriving at every dislocation line like someone
finally remembering their purpose.

After enough time the phase changes again—the crystal lattice
dissolves entirely into its elements—and what remains
on the nut's thread is a white powder looser than anything
the bolt ever was, each atom gone from its position
but still there, still doing something: contributing to friction,
stopping things before they stop.

The poem ends where it began:
a steel bar emerging red from the billet mold,
already cooled to a hull of habit.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The central conceit — time as a physical force acting on an object through metallurgical processes, never named but always present — is genuinely compelling. The passage where the writer describes heat treating and work hardening without once naming "aging" or "time" earns its place: *something happens at the molecular level: some dislocations / step forward, others are trapped, the lattice reorganizes*. That's precise observation doing the work of poetry.

The drill bit sequence is one of the strongest moments. The chips curl off in a spiral that looks like deposition rather than subtraction — "cutting is not subtraction, it's interruption." This is where the writing stops explaining and starts *showing* how language about objects can carry time without naming it.

The closing return to the billet mold works as an epigraphic gesture: the opening image of a red-hot bar has been transformed into something else by the poem's labor; returning there makes "already cooled to a hull of habit" land with new weight. The object *has* changed, and so has the language around it.

The writer's commitment to metallurgical accuracy is genuinely impressive — this isn't decorative, it's structural. That matters.

---

### What Isn't Working

**1. Overcrowded syntax / sentence bloat (structural issue, lines 3–40)**
The single unbroken sentence stretches from line 3 roughly through line 40 without a genuine breath or pivot. The passage becomes hard to parse at exactly the point where it should be most alive — when *something* is happening that hasn't happened before. Direction: break into shorter sentences or clauses where tension between syntax and image can create double meaning. Right now the sentence is doing everything, which means nothing lands with force.

**2. The "language losing its grammar" passage (abstraction breaking the metaphor)**
Line 37 — *it pools like a language losing its grammar* — collapses the poem's domain into something generic and literary. After thousands of precise metallurgical details, this line reaches for analogy that is *worse* than the clichés the brief banned. Direction: cut or replace with another physical image. The liquid iron gathering at the cut face (line 34) already does this work — "softened / enough to sag" is more vivid and literal.

**3. Redundancy and repetition without escalation**
The poem says "work hardening" three times in lines 26–28, and "grain structure" appears twice in a single sentence (lines 29–30). Each instance of repetition should deepen or shift meaning — here they flatten it. Direction: each use of key technical terms like "work hardening," "grain structure," "dislocations" must arrive with new information.

**4. Cliché proximity**
Even within the domain, some phrasing reads as cliché by

revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The core commitment — to render time through metallurgy without naming "time" or "aging" — is the strongest engine here. The passage where dislocations step forward and grains reorganize in the heat treatment (lines 12–16) has genuine tension between syntax and image: "some dislocations / step forward, others are trapped, the lattice reorganizes." That line break at "step" creates a double meaning — the word physically enacts movement. The drill bit sequence (lines 30–35) also works because it stops explaining and starts showing: "a softer version behind" is precise without sentiment.

The closing return to the billet mold earns its place; the opening image returns transformed, and "already cooled to a hull of habit" lands with new weight precisely because so much has happened between those lines.

### What Isn't Working

**1. Overcrowded syntax / sentence bloat (structural issue)**
The single unbroken sentence runs from line 3 roughly through line 40 without a genuine syntactic or imagistic turn. The passage becomes hard to parse at exactly the point where it should be most alive — when *something* is happening that hasn't happened before. Direction: break into shorter sentences or clauses. Let syntax create tension by splitting where a word's double meaning can split light. Right now the sentence is doing everything, which means nothing lands with force.

**2. The "language losing its grammar" passage (abstraction breaking the metaphor)**
Line 37 — *it pools like a language losing its grammar* — collapses the poem's domain into something generic and literary. After thousands of precise metallurgical details, this line reaches for analogy that is worse than the clichés the brief banned. Direction: cut or replace with another physical image. The liquid iron gathering at the cut face (line 34) already does this work — "softened / enough to sag" is more vivid and literal.

**3. Redundancy without escalation**
The poem says "work hardening" three times in lines 26–28, and "grain structure" appears twice in a single sentence (lines 29–30). Each use of key technical terms must arrive with new information or risk flattening the reader's experience. Direction: each use of "work hardening," "grain structure," "dislocations" should deepen rather than repeat.

**4. Proximity to cliché in phrasing**
Even within the domain, some phrasing reads as cliché by proximity:
- **"yield strength defined" (line 10) — this is a technical phrase doing no poetic work; cut or replace with an image of load
- **"not named" / "not rust but" (lines 25–26) — these are explanations the reader can't feel without sensory substitution
-

revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The passage from "A steel bar emerges from the billet mold" through to "and what happens is work hardening: grains resist further deformation by tightening their bonds, / a kind of crystalline anxiety — the surface darkens / through atomic abrasion rather than corrosion —" works because it earns its complexity. The single sentence there moves from macro (dislocations stepping forward) to micro (atomic abrasion), and each clause advances with genuine syntactic tension that mirrors how the material actually behaves. "The grains pile up against each other in that small circle until the bolt threads seize / on their own mating nut as if on a mineral lode" is precise, physical, and earns its metaphor — it doesn't explain what work hardening means; it shows what happens.

The closing return to the billet mold ("A steel bar emerges red from the billet mold, / already cooled to a hull of habit") lands with real weight because so much has been built. The opening image returns transformed: "hull of habit" is doing something specific — it suggests enclosure without rigidity, and that word "habit" carries a faint echo of routine or conditioning that resonates with the poem's subject.

The drill bit passage ("a softer version behind") works because it trusts the reader to feel what's happening. The phrase "yield layer by layer" is physically precise and doesn't need to say "this is how metal yields."

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Syntactic bloat (structural issue)**
The single unbroken sentence runs from line 3 roughly through line 40 without a genuine syntactic or imagistic turn. The passage becomes hard to parse at exactly the point where it should be most alive — when *something* is happening that hasn't happened before. **Direction:** Break into shorter sentences or clauses. Let syntax create tension by splitting where a word's double meaning can split light. Right now the sentence is doing everything, which means nothing lands with force.

**Abstraction breaking the metaphor (line 37)**
"Still carrying heat as property rather than temperature" — this is explanation dressed in abstraction. The poem has already shown what this means: the bar sagging into a "small lake blacker / than any lake." **Direction:** Cut or replace with another physical image. The liquid iron gathering at the cut face (line 34) does more work.

**Redundancy without escalation**
"Work hardening" appears three times in lines 26–28, and "grain structure" appears twice in a single sentence (lines 29–30). **Direction:** Each use of key technical terms must arrive with new information or risk flattening the reader's experience. Line 27 ("At this point the heat has left / but not been missed") is pure explanation — it tells rather than shows.

A steel bar emerges from the billet mold,
already cooled to a hull of habit, gray
and still red at its center.

It is transferred to the forge where air finds its work and carbon dissolves
into the matrix as an atom would dissolve
into another atom's dance. The grains rearrange themselves
along grain boundaries they never crossed before,
all of this while still red-hot and held
in tongs that do not compress but align —
as fingers might grip a shape without crushing it.

The bar is bent twice its length and kept there—
a curve like a question it will not undo—and sent to the press.
Under pressure larger than any force it carried when drawn from fire,
dislocations step forward, others trapped,
the lattice reorganizes with fewer defects. Still glowing,

it is cut with a saw that does not grind but slices
through by virtue of being thin and hard —
and from the cut face iron and carbon gather:
not molten in the sense of boiling, softened
enough to sag into a small lake blacker
than any lake — this is what happens
when an object gives up its crystalline order entirely.

The cylinder is swaged next—reduced by repeated passes through dies getting smaller,
each one leaving the metal slightly denser. At this point the heat has left
but not been missed—the grain structure has locked into place
with no memory of its history except stiffness.

and what happens is work hardening: grains resist further deformation by tightening their bonds,
a kind of crystalline anxiety — the surface darkens
through atomic abrasion rather than corrosion —

this object has been shaped by forces that had no name for it.

A drill bit presses into the side wall, advances in chip sizes too small to see with naked eye,
and what the metal does is yield layer by layer, each grain sliding past its neighbor like water finding fissures
in the rock over hundred thousand years — this is how the bore is made:
not by removing material but by teaching it a new pore.

The bolt goes into assembly. Under load
it yields at its thread roots and work hardens there—the grains pile up against each other in that small circle until the bolt threads seize
on their own mating nut as if on a mineral lode — here the object has reached its most solid phase:

not heat treated but pressure set.

The bar sits in soil. Iron begins to diffuse
from grain to grain where it meets carbon—this is why buried steel rusts from the inside out: anion vacancies
arriving at every dislocation line like someone
finally remembering their purpose.

After enough time, the phase changes again — the crystal lattice dissolves entirely into its elements,
and what remains on the nut's thread is a white powder looser than anything
the bolt ever was. Each atom gone from its position still there,

final_poem:
A steel bar emerges from the billet mold,
already cooled to a hull of habit, gray
and still red at its center.

It is transferred to the forge where air finds its work and carbon dissolves
into the matrix as an atom would dissolve
into another atom's dance. The grains rearrange themselves
along grain boundaries they never crossed before,
all of this while still red-hot and held
in tongs that do not compress but align —
as fingers might grip a shape without crushing it.

The bar is bent twice its length and kept there—
a curve like a question it will not undo—and sent to the press.
Under pressure larger than any force it carried when drawn from fire,
dislocations step forward, others trapped,
the lattice reorganizes with fewer defects. Still glowing,

it is cut with a saw that does not grind but slices
through by virtue of being thin and hard —
and from the cut face iron and carbon gather:
not molten in the sense of boiling, softened
enough to sag into a small lake blacker
than any lake — this is what happens
when an object gives up its crystalline order entirely.

The cylinder is swaged next—reduced by repeated passes through dies getting smaller,
each one leaving the metal slightly denser. At this point the heat has left
but not been missed—the grain structure has locked into place
with no memory of its history except stiffness.

On a shelf in a warehouse temperature fluctuates with weather—

and what happens is work hardening: grains resist further deformation by tightening their bonds,
a kind of crystalline anxiety — the surface darkens
through atomic abrasion rather than corrosion —

this object has been shaped by forces that had no name for it.

A drill bit presses into the side wall, advances in chip sizes too small to see with naked eye,
and what the metal does is yield layer by layer, each grain sliding past its neighbor like water finding fissures
in the rock over hundred thousand years — this is how the bore is made:
not by removing material but by teaching it a new pore.

The bolt goes into assembly. Under load
it yields at its thread roots and work hardens there—the grains pile up against each other in that small circle until the bolt threads seize
on their own mating nut as if on a mineral lode — here the object has reached its most solid phase:

not heat treated but pressure set.

The bar sits in soil. Iron begins to diffuse
from grain to grain where it meets carbon—this is why buried steel rusts from the inside out: anion vacancies
arriving at every dislocation line like someone
finally remembering their purpose.

After enough time, the phase changes again — the crystal lattice dissolves entirely into its elements,
and what remains on the nut's thread is a white powder looser than anything
the bolt ever was. Each atom gone from its position still there,
still doing something: contributing to friction, stopping things before they stop.
